title: What is the most limited octave range a person can have and still be a singer? - Quora

response.answer_text: I like that counter-intuitive question. Not everyone can attain the range of a top opera singer, even with a lot of training. Some people do seem to have a range of just about one octave, yet are successful. Suzanne Vega comes to mind. She has barely any range, yet she’s had some big hits. To be honest, I don’t care much for her voice even though her songs are appealing. I like a sound with more fire and expression, and that involves range. If you don’t have much of a range, you’ll need things that make up for it. You’d need a sound that is at least appealing, even if it’s not dramatic and powerful. I think the most important way to overcome small range is to have very appealing tunes, and Suzanne has that. A small voice needs killer tunes!  By the way, if you don’t have designs on fame and fortune, a small voice will work just fine in a choir, or just singing for fun.

I remember, back in the 90s, a “divas” episode of Oprah that had Whitney Houston, Mariah Carey, and Amy Grant in their prime… primes? Anyway, Oprah went down the line asking each singer about herself. When she got to Grant, Amy said something along the lines of not really feeling like she belonged in that group since, as she put it, she had “only about an octave range.” If you’re talking about just casual, around-the-house singing, I would say any range would be fine, but you’re severly limited in repertoire if you can’t exceed an octave. If you’re talking about an actual performance range, I would say not less than an octave plus a fourth (e.g., from C4-F5); and even an octave plus a fifth would almost double the repertoire you could cover.
